data.name: eQual course
data.title: eQual course
data.subtitle: Discover PHP and Equal framework
data.description:
This course is designed to take you through all aspects of the eQual framework, from setting it up and configuring it, to using its features and understanding its core architecture. Whether you're just starting out or looking to deepen your expertise, this course will equip you with the knowledge and skills needed to develop efficient, scalable web applications using the eQual framework.


Course Objectives:

  • Install and Configure eQual: Learn how to properly set up the framework using Docker or manual methods, and configure it to create a fully functional development environment.


  • Navigate Framework Usage: Understand how to access and use the eQual dashboard, and execute essential commands to interact with the framework.


  • Work with Packages: Learn the structure of eQual packages and how to create new ones to extend the framework's functionality.


  • Learn PHP Basics: Gain a solid understanding of PHP fundamentals, ensuring you're equipped to write efficient code within the framework.


  • Understand Key Architecture Concepts: Explore core architectural concepts like ORM, routing, and authorization, enabling you to build scalable and maintainable applications.

data.title: Installation
data.description: This module covers the complete installation process for the eQual framework. It walks you through preparing your environment, installing the framework, and configuring it for use.

data.title: Usage
data.description: This module introduces you to using the eQual framework once it's installed. It focuses on how to access the dashboard and utilize important commands for managing the system.

data.title: Package ( basics )
data.description: In this module, you'll explore how the eQual framework is structured around packages. You will learn the structure of a package and how to create your own.

data.title: PHP base
data.description: This module covers the foundational concepts of PHP, the programming language used by eQual. It is perfect for those new to PHP or in need of a refresher.

data.title: Architecture concepts
data.description: This module delves into the architectural concepts that form the backbone of the eQual framework, helping you build scalable and maintainable applications.

data.title: Preconfiguration
data.description: Before starting the installation, you'll learn how to preconfigure your system, including setting up a virtual host and preparing your environment for a smooth installation of eQual.

data.title: Configuration
data.description: This chapter covers how to configure the eQual framework after installation. You'll learn how to create and manage the config.json file manually or by generating it with a command-line tool.

data.title: Initialization
data.description: In this chapter, you will initialize both the eQual database and its core packages, making your installation fully operational and ready for development.

data.title: Access to the eQual dashboard
data.description: You'll learn how to access and navigate the eQual dashboard, which serves as the control center for managing your application.

data.title: eQual commands
data.description: This chapter explores various eQual commands that allow you to interact with the framework via the command line, from basic management to advanced operations.

data.title: Package structure
data.description: Understand the core structure of an eQual package, including the role of each component and file in the package's operation.

data.title: Create a new package
data.description: This chapter provides a step-by-step guide on how to create a new package in eQual, from defining the package to registering it within the framework.

data.title: Introduction
data.description: An introduction to PHP, covering its role in web development and its integration with the eQual framework.

data.title: Variables
data.description: Learn about PHP variables, how to declare them, and their role in storing and managing data within the application.

data.title: Types
data.description: This chapter focuses on PHP's data types, such as integers, strings, arrays, and objects, and how they are used in programming.

data.title: Operators
data.description: Understand how to use operators in PHP, including arithmetic, comparison, and logical operators to perform operations on variables and data.

data.title: Control structures
data.description: Explore control structures such as if/else statements, loops, and switch cases, which help manage the flow of the application.

data.title: ORM
data.description: Learn about ORM, the technique that allows you to map PHP objects to database tables, making data management easier.

data.title: Domain
data.description: This chapter explains the domain layer of the eQual framework, which handles the business logic of your application.

data.title: Controller
data.description: Understand the role of the controller in the MVC (Model-View-Controller) architecture, which handles requests and prepares data for the view.

data.title: Routing
data.description: Learn how routing works in eQual, directing incoming requests to the appropriate controller and method based on the URL.

data.title: Views
data.description: This chapter covers the view layer, responsible for rendering the user interface and presenting data to the user in a structured manner.

data.title: I18n
data.description: Learn about internationalization, or I18n, which allows your application to support multiple languages and cultural formats.

data.title: Authorization
data.description: This final chapter introduces the concept of authorization within eQual, helping you manage user permissions and secure access to different parts of the application.

data.content:
Before installing the eQual framework, you need to have these prerequisites below.


Set up your virtual host file to point to `equal.local`:


  • Windows: `C:\Windows\System32\drivers\etc\hosts`
  • Linux: `/etc/hosts`


Add the following line to your host file:
Choose one of the following installation methods:

The prerequisites for using eQual with Docker are:


  • Docker Desktop
  • WSL2 (Windows Subsystem for Linux)

• Clone the docker-compose file: This file contains the necessary configurations to run eQual in a Docker

  container.

• Docker desktop: Docker Desktop for Windows - x86_64
  • WSL2: Execute in the PowerShell

The prerequisite for a manual installation are:


  • Wampserver: Wampserver 3.3.5 64 bit x64 - Apache 2.4.59 - PHP 7.4.33/8.0.30/8.1.28/8.2.18/8.3.6 - MySQL 8.3.0 - MariaDB 11.3.2

For configuring the application you have two choices:


  • Create manually the config file
  • Generate the config with a controller

Create a `config.json` file in the config directory.


Add the following content to the `config.json` file:
Run the following command to generate the configuration file:
Run the following command for initializing the database:
Run the following command for initializing the core package:

Open your browser and go to equal.local which is the default url.


If you change your host file and your config you can change your site domain url.


You can log in using the following credentials to the login page equal.local/auth:

  • Email: root@equal.local
  • Password: secure_password

With the eQual framework, you have multiple choices to interact with the system. You can use the following command to

see how to retrieve the root user:
There are two types of commands in eQual:

Read command (get) This command is used to read data from the database. You can use this command to read a single

 record or multiple records.


Write command (do): This command is used to write data to the database or perform some actions.

You can use this command for:

  • Create, update, or delete records in the database.
  • Perform some actions like sending an email, initializing database and packages, etc.


Show command (show): This command is used to display formatted data. You can use this command to display data in a specific format. For example, you can use this command to:

  • Display a PDF file.
  • Display the Discord server.

You can find commands in two folders inside each package that are installed in the eQualFramework:


  • data: This folder contains the commands that are used to get data from.
  • action: This folder contains the commands that are used to perform some actions.


The two next images show the structure of the core package for the data and action folders:

For example, if you want to get the user data, you can find the command in the core package in the data folder.


For retrieving data from the database, eQual use Model pattern which is called class in the framework to manage the data.


You can find more information about specific Models in the classes folder inside each package.

1. Localise the package name
  2. Call the command name action as do or data as get
  3. Localise which data or action you want to perform
  • Example, if you want to create a new User, there is a controller for that at /packages/core/actions/user/create.php
  • For executing the command and pass each folder for retrieve it, you need to replace each / with _ and the filename without it's extension
  • By default the core package is used in the call path, you need to write your package name at the beginning of the call

The eQual framework is package oriented. Each package contains a set of functionalities that can be used in your

application.


In this chapter, you'll see how to initialize a new package and how to initialize a Class in your application.


Each package has the following structure:

• actions: This folder contains the commands that are used to perform some actions.
  • classes: This folder contains the classes model that are used to manage the data.
  • data: This folder contains the commands that are used to get data from.
  • i18n: This folder contains the translations for the package.
  • init: This folder contains the initialization files for the package, like assets, default data, routes, etc.
  • tests: This folder contains the tests for the package.
  • views: This folder contains the views for the package.
  • manifest.json: This file contains the package information like name, version, description, etc.

To create a new package, you need to follow these steps:


Create a new folder in the `packages` directory:

  • The folder name should be the package name.
  • The package name should be in lowercase.


Create the package structure:

  • Create the following files and folders in the package directory:
  • manifest.json
  • classes

```json

{

 "name": "yourPackageName",

 "version": "0.0.1",

 "description": "Your package description",

 "authors": [

  "Your name"

 ],

 "license": "LGPL-3.0",

 "tags": [

  "your",

  "tags",

  "like what's you package do"

 ],

 "depends_on": [

  "do you package depend on another package ?"

 ],

 "require": [

  "what's your package need to composer dependencies ?"

 ],

 "apps": [

  "if your package has apps, list them here"

 ]

}
Create a new class in the classes folder. For example, call it Task so the file must be called Task.class.php.

```php


namespace YourPackageName;


use equal\orm\Model;


class Task extends Model {

  public static function getColumns() {

    return [

      'title'   => ['type' => 'string'],

      'content'  => ['type' => 'text']

    ];

  }

}

For filling your Task table, you need to create init data in the init/data folder. For example, create a file

called yourPackageName_task.json


Put the following content in the file:

```json

{

 "name": "yourPackageName\\Task",

 "lang": "en",

 "data": [

  {

   "title": "Task 1",

   "content": "This is the content of the task 1"

  },

  {

   "title": "Task 2",

   "content": "This is the content of the task 2"

  }

 ]

}
For using your new Class, you need to initialize your package. You can do this by running the following command:

The initialization of a package allows to:


  • Create the database tables
  • Moving the assets to the public directory to access it from the browser
  • Add the routes for accessing the package actions and datas
  • Add the translations for the package
  • Add the default data for the package

```json

[

 {

  "id": 1,

  "state": "instance",

  "name": "Task 1",

  "title": "Task 1",

  "content": "This is the content of the task 1"

 },

 {

  "id": 2,

  "state": "instance",

  "name": "Task 2",

  "title": "Task 2",

  "content": "This is the content of the task 2"

 }

]

You've learned how to create a new package in the eQual framework.


You've created a Task class, it's init data and initialized the package.
PHP is a server-side scripting language that is used to develop web applications. It's a powerful tool for making dynamic and interactive web pages.

For beginning with PHP, you need to know the different types of data that you can use in PHP. What's a string, a number.

How to use variables, functions, and operators.

How to perform an action with some condition ? how to repeat an action a set number of times ? And how to access the

values of an array and object ?


We'll respond to these question in the next of this course.

Before beginning with the first chapter, you need to know two function used by PHP for output the data:


  • echo: It's used to output data, like that I show you the variable output.
  • print_r: It's used to output the structure of a variable like PHP handles it.

For using the eQual framework, you need to know the basics of PHP. In this chapter, see the basic of PHP.


A variable is used to store data. In PHP, a variable starts with the $ sign, followed by the name of the variable.

Like all other programming languages, PHP has a set of types which are used to define the variables. In the next pages of this chapter, you'll see the most used types in PHP.


There is a list of type we go to learn in this chapter:


  1. String
  2. Integer
  3. Float
  4. Boolean
  5. Null
  6. Array
  7. Class & object
  8. Function

Operators are used to perform operations on variables and values.


PHP has the following types of operators:

• Arithmetic operators: Used to perform arithmetic operations.
  • Assignment operators: Used to assign values to variables.
  • Comparison operators: Used to compare two values.
  • Logical operators: Used to combine conditional statements.


For explaining each type of operators, we'll see the cases with these four variables:

Control structure is used for controlling the flow of the program execution. They're used to perform different actions based on different conditions.


PHP has the following types of control structures:


require: Requires a file to be included, and it's used when the file is required by the application.

If statement: Executes some code if one condition is true.

If...else statement: Executes some code if a condition is true or another code if the condition is false.

If...elseif...else statement: Executes different codes for more than two conditions.

If the first condition is false, it checks the next condition.

If the second condition (elseif) is false, it executes the code in the ``else`` block.

Switch statement: Selects one of many blocks of code to be executed.

While loop: Executes some code as long as a condition is true.

Do...while loop: Executes some code once and then repeats the execution as long as a condition is true.

For loop: Executes some code a set number of times.

Foreach loop: Executes some code for each element in an array.


They're other control structures, but these are the most used. Let's see theses control structures in the next pages.

The require statement is used to include a file in the application.


For example, if you have a file named math.php that contains the following code:
You can include this file in another file using the require statement:

The if statement is used to execute some code if a condition is true.


For example, let's reuse the previous $totalPrice variable and check if the value is greater than 10:

```php

if ($totalPrice > 10) {

  echo "The total price is greater than 10.";

}


// Output: The total price is greater than 10 because the total price is 15.

The if...else statement is used to execute some code if a condition is true or another code if the condition is false.


For example, let's reuse the previous $totalPrice variable and check if the value is greater than 10:

```php

if ($totalPrice > 10) {

  echo "The total price is greater than 10.";

} else {

  echo "The total price is less than or equal to 10.";

}


// Output: The total price is greater than 10 because the total price is 15.

The if...elseif...else statement is used to execute different codes for more than two conditions.


For example, let's reuse the previous $totalPrice variable and check if the value is greater than 10, equal to 10 or

less than 10:

```php

if ($totalPrice > 10) {

  echo "The total price is greater than 10.";

} elseif ($totalPrice == 10) {

  echo "The total price is equal to 10.";

} else {

  echo "The total price is less than 10.";

}


// Output: The total price is greater than 10 because the total price is 15.

The switch statement is used to select one of many blocks of code to be executed. It can be used as an alternative to the if...elseif...else statement.


For example, let's reuse the previous $totalPrice variable and check if the value is greater than 10, equal to 10 or less than 10:

```php

switch ($totalPrice) {

  case ($totalPrice > 10):

    echo "The total price is greater than 10.";

    break;

  case ($totalPrice == 10):

    echo "The total price is equal to 10.";

    break;

  default:

    echo "The total price is less than 10.";

}


// Output: The total price is greater than 10 because the total price is 15.

In the previous example, you used the switch statement with the $totalPrice variable.


You have view three other words inside this control structure:


case: It's used to check if the value of the variable is equal to the value of the case.

break: It's used to stop the execution of the switch statement.

default: It's used to execute the code if none of the cases are true.


The switch statement can be used without for each case a break condition. In this case, the switch statement will execute for multiple cases the same code.

```php

$animal = "dog";


switch ($animal) {

  case "dog":

  case "cat":

  case "rabbit":

  case "hamster":

  case "parrot":

  case "goldfish":

    echo "The animal is a pet.";

    break;

  case "lion":

  case "tiger":

    echo "The animal is a wild animal.";

    break;

  default:

    echo "The animal is not a pet or a wild animal.";

}


// Output: The animal is a pet because the animal is a dog.

The while loop is used to execute some code as long as a condition is true.


For example, let's use an initial value of 0 and increment it by 1 until it reaches 5:

```php

$initialValue = 0;


while ($initialValue < 5) {

  echo $initialValue;

  $initialValue++; // The ++ operator is used to increment the value by 1.

}


// Output: 01234

The do...while loop is used to execute some code once same if at the base the condition is false and then repeats the execution as long as a condition is true.


The do keyword is like a free pass for the first execution.


For example, let's do an example with an initial value of 0 and increment it by 2 until it reaches 5,

for this example the condition is false at the beginning but the code is executed once so the output will be 024:

```php

$initialValue = 0;


do {

  echo $initialValue;

  $initialValue += 2; // The += operator is used to increment the value by 2.

} while ($initialValue > 1 && $initialValue < 5);


// Output: 024

The for loop is used to execute some code a set number of times.


For example, let's use the for loop to display the numbers from 0 to 4:

For explaining the for loop, there's three parts:


  • The first part is the initialization of the variable $i with value 0.
  • The second part is the condition to execute the code, in this case, the condition is to execute the code while the value of the variable $i is less than 5.
  • The third part is the incrementation of the variable $i by 1 at the end of the block of code.

The foreach loop is used to execute some code for each element in an array.


For example, let's use the foreach loop to display the values of an array:

ORM stands for Object-Relational Mapping. It is widely used inside the eQual framework to manage the data.


If you want to manipule some data, you can use the ORM to interact with the database for creating, reading, updating, or

deleting data.


There's one class inside the ORM that is used always for the manipulation of the data, it's the Collection class,

which use the ObjectManager class for the interaction with the database.


The Collection class is used to manage a collection of objects.

The ObjectManager methods are used on the Model classes to interact with the database.


Both class are co-dependent, the Collection class is used to manage a collection of objects, and

the ObjectManager class is used to interact with the database.


For manipulating the data, often the Collection class is used.

There's the most used methods of the Collection class:


  • id: Returns a collection of objects with the specified id.
  • ids: Returns a collection of objects with the specified ids.
  • first: Returns the first object in the collection.
  • last: Returns the last object in the collection.
  • from: Returns a collection of objects starting from the specified index.
  • limit: Returns a limited number of objects from the collection.
  • count: Returns the number of objects in the collection.
  • search: Returns a collection of objects matching the domain criteria.
  • create: Creates a new object instance.
  • validate: Checks whether the values of a given object fields are consistent with the related model definition.
  • update: Sets new values for one or more object instances.
  • delete: Deletes the objects permanently from the database.

A relationship is a connection between two objects in the database.


They are three types of relationships in the eQual framework:


  • many2one: many objects can be related to one object.
  • one2many: one object can be related to many objects.
  • many2many: many objects can be related to many objects.

For example, let's create the relationship between the Task and the User objects.

The Task object can be related to one User object.

Let's add the user_id field to the Task object:

```php

class User extends Model {

   public static function getColumns() {

       return [

           ...

           'user_id'  => [

               'type' => 'one2many',

               'foreign_object' => 'yourPackageName\Task',

               'foreign_key' => 'user_id'

           ]

       ];

   }

}
Like this, the Task object can be related to one User object.

For example, let's create the relationship between the Task and the User objects.


The Task object can be related to many User objects.

Let's add the task_id field to the User object:

```php

class User extends Model {

   public static function getColumns() {

       return [

           ...,

           'task_id'  => [

               'type' => 'many2one',

               'foreign_object' => 'yourPackageName\Task'

           ]

       ];

   }

}
Like this, the Task object can be related to many User objects.

For example, let's create the relationship between the Task and the User objects.

The Task objects can be related to many User objects and many User objects can be related to many Tasks.

Let's add the task_ids field to the User object:

In this chapter, you've learned the Collection methods, relationships, the basics of the ORM in the eQual framework.


In the next chapter, you'll see how to use the domain criteria to filter the data.
A Domain is essentially a structure that defines a set of conditions used to create filtered lists of objects.

```php

$domain = [                                      // domain

   [                                             // clause

       [

           '{operand}', '{operator}', '{value}'  // condition

       ],

       [

           '{operand}', '{operator}', '{value}'  // another contition (AND)

       ]

   ],

   [                                             // another clause (OR)

       [

           '{operand}', '{operator}', '{value}'  // condition

       ],

       [

           '{operand}', '{operator}', '{value}'  // another contition (AND)

       ]

   ]

];
It's created with an array of conditions, each condition is an array with three elements:

• operand: The field name of the object. In the case of the Task it can be title or content.
  • operator: The operator to use for the comparison. It can be one of these values:

   - =: Equal

   - <>: Not equal

   - <: Less than

   - >: Greater than

   - <=: Less than or equal to

   - >=: Greater than or equal to

   - like: Like

   - ilike: Case-insensitive like

   - in: In a list

   - contains: Contains

  • value: The value to compare with the field.
A clause is a list of conditions, it can be used to group the conditions with the same logic.

```php

// there's AND logic between the conditions

$andClause = [ $condition, $condition ];


// there's OR logic between the conditions

$orClause = [ [$condition], [$condition] ];

In this chapter, you've learned the basics of Domain in the eQual framework.


The chapter was necessary to understand the domain argument in the search method of the Collection class.

The controllers can be placed in two directories:


  • data: For the data controllers
  • action: For the action controllers


The controllers are used to manage the data and the actions of the package.

They're four parts in a controller structure:


  • Announce: The announce function is used to declare the controller.

  - description: The description of the controller.

 - params: The parameters of the controller.

 - response: The response of the controller expected.

 - constants: The application constants used in the controller.

 - providers: The providers used in the controller.

 - access visibility: The access of the controller.

     - public: The controller is accessible by everyone.

     - protected: user must be authenticated for accessing the controller.

     - private: Is only allowed for the command-line tool.

  • list of the providers: The list of the providers used in the controller.
  • controller logic: The logic of the controller.
  • response: The response of the controller.

announce

  • The announce function is used to declare the controller, it's the first part of the controller.


List of providers

  • In the next page you can look the list of the providers used in the controller logic.


controller logic

  • This is the part where the logic of the controller is placed.


response

  • The response of the controller is the last part of the controller.


You can use the context provider httpResponse method for sending the response.

report

  • equal\error\Reporter  
  • Intercepts, handles, and filters error and exceptions messages and stores them into a log file.


auth

  • equal\auth\AuthenticationManager
  • Manages the credentials & authentication tokens.


access

  • equal\access\AccessController
  • Manages the access/permissions of User & Groups to entities & controllers.


context

  • equal\php\Context
  • Manages the HTTP requests & responses.


validate

  • equal\data\DataValidator
  • Checks the fields consistency of entities & controllers.

adapt

  • equal\data\DataAdapterProvider
  • DAP provides DataAdapters for transforming the data to the needed type (example: string to date).


orm

  • equal\orm\ObjectManager
  • Manages the objects (classes).


route

  • equal\route\Router
  • Returns an existing route.


spool

  • equal\email\EmailSpooler
  • Manages the emails.

report

  • equal\error\Reporter  
  • Intercepts, handles, and filters error and exceptions messages and stores them into a log file.


auth

  • equal\auth\AuthenticationManager
  • Manages the credentials & authentication tokens.


access

  • equal\access\AccessController
  • Manages the access/permissions of User & Groups to entities & controllers.


context

  • equal\php\Context
  • Manages the HTTP requests & responses.


validate

  • equal\data\DataValidator
  • Checks the fields consistency of entities & controllers.

adapt

  • equal\data\DataAdapterProvider
  • DAP provides DataAdapters for transforming the data to the needed type (example: string to date).


orm

  • equal\orm\ObjectManager
  • Manages the objects (classes).


route

  • equal\route\Router
  • Returns an existing route.


spool

  • equal\email\EmailSpooler
  • Manages the emails.

The data controllers are used for making API endpoint to get the data.


For example, let's create a data controller called index.php for the Task object:

```php

use yourPackageName\Task;


// The announce function is used to declare the controller

list($params, $providers) = announce([

   'description'  => 'Retrieve the list of existing tasks and their corresponding users',

   'params'       => [],

   'response'     => [

                       'content-type' => 'application/json',

                       'charset'      => 'utf-8',

                       'accept-origin' => ['*']

                      ],

   'providers'    => ['context'],

   'access'       => [

       'visibility'       => 'protected'

   ],

]);

```php

// The list of the providers used in the controller logic

list($context) = [ $providers['context'] ];


// The controller logic

$tasks = Task::search([])

       ->read(['id', 'title', 'content', 'user_id' => ['id', 'name']])

       ->adapt('json')

       ->get(true);


// The response of the controller

$context->httpResponse()

       ->status(200)

       ->body($tasks)

       ->send();

The action controllers are used for making API endpoint to perform actions.


For example, let's create an action controller called create.php for the Task object:

The routing is used to define the URL of the controllers.


The routes are defined in a file called ${priorityNumber}-${packageName}.json in the package directory.


  • ${priorityNumber}: The priority number of the route, the lower the number, the higher is the priority.
  • ${packageName}: The name of the ressource.


For example, let's create a route for the Task object. The route file can be called 99-tasks.json :

```php

{

 "/tasks": {

   "GET": {

     "description": "Retrieve the list of existing tasks and their corresponding users",

     "operation": "?get=yourPackageName_task_index"

   },

   "POST": {

     "description": "Create a new task",

     "operation": "?get=yourPackageName_task_create"

   }

 }

}

Now than you have the model and data, the actions and the routes, you need to display the data to the user.


The views are used to display the data to the user.


The views are placed in the views directory of the package.


They are multiple types of views:


dashboard: Used to display a dashboard.

form: Used to display a form.

list: Used to display a list of objects.

menu: Used to display a menu.

search: Used to display a search form.

chart: Used to display a chart.

The view files are JSON files that give you the possibility to define a view for your application.


A view file has a big amount of line, so I'll show you the structure of a view file in multiple parts.


For being more concise, I'll describe you all properties of the views.

There are plenty of properties which are repeated in different types of views.


So I'll show you the properties of the dashboard view in this example, but the views are almost the same.

name: The name of the view.

description: The description of the view.

layout (object): It contains the groups property.

groups (array): It contains some group objects.


group (object)

   - label (string): This is the label of the group.

   - height (string): This is the height of the group in percentage.

   - sections (array): It contains some section objects.


section (object)

   - rows (array): It contains some row objects.

row (object)

   - height (string): This is the height of the row in percentage.

   - columns (array): It contains some column objects.


column (object)

   - width (string): This is the width of the column in percentage.

   - items (array): It contains some item objects.


item (object): It contains the following properties:

   - id (string): This is the unique id of the item.

   - label (string): This is the label of the item.

   - description (string): This is the description of the item.

   - width (string): This is the width of the item in percentage.

   - entity (string): This is the entity of the item.

   - view (string): This is the view of the item.

   - domain (array): This is the domain of the item.

```json

{

 "name": "Assignments",

 "description": "List of existing Role assignments granted to users.",

 "layout": {

   "items": [

     {

       "type": "field",

       "value": "id",

       "width": "10%"

     },

     {

       "type": "field",

       "value": "object_class",

       "width": "20%",

       "widget": {

         "sortable": true

       }

     }

   ]

 }

}

Each item is a table column, the properties of the items are:


  • type: The type of the item.
  • value: The property key of the item.
  • width: The width of the item in percentage.
  • widget (optional): The widget of the item, in this case, it's for render this column sortable.

The form view is like a dashboard view in its structure like: layout => groups => sections => rows => columns => items.


In the form views, the group is more used because it marks with more space the different parts of the form.


In this exemple at layout => groups => sections => rows, the columns is like this:

```json

{

 "columns": [

   {

     "width": "33%",

     "align": "left",

     "items": [

       {

         "type": "field",

         "value": "name",

         "width": "100%",

         "label": "Group name",

         "help": "Unique ID of the group.",

         "widget": {

           // It's for render the field as a textarea field.

           "type": "text",

           // The heading widget is used to display the label of the field as a heading.

           "heading": true

         }

       }

     ]

   }

 ]

}

In the same file, you can have multiple sections. Each section is a part of the form.


I show you the structure of the section in the form view:

The menu view is used to display a menu.


Menu structure:

```json

{

 "id": "Identifier of the item (used for translations).",

 "label": "Title of the item to display within the menu.",

 "description (optional)": "Short string explaining the purpose of the item (the view it leads to).",

 "icon (optional)": "Icon to show aside the item.",

 "type": "Either 'entry' or 'parent'. In case an item is a 'parent', it also have a 'children' property.",

 "children (array)": [

   "...menu entries..."

 ]

}

The menu object view is used to display a menu object.


Menu object structure:

```json

{

 "id": "The unique identifier of the object.",

 // The type of the item, it can be a parent or an entry.

 "type": "entry",

 "label": "Label of the object.",

 "description": "Description of the object",

 "context": {

   "entity": "targeted_entity like myPackageName\\Task",

   // Name of the view

   "view": "list.default",

   // Name of the property

   "order": "name",

   "sort": "'asc' | 'desc'",

   "domain (optional)": "Like a domain: [condition, ...]"

 }

}

The search view is used to display a search form for searching the data and show the results in a structured way.


Search view structure:

```json

{

 // Exemple based on a search view for a products catalog

 "name": "Name of the search view",

 "description": "Description of the collector",

 "layout": {

   "groups": [{

       "sections": [{

           "rows": [{

               "columns": [{

                   "width": "100%",

                   "items": [

                     {

                       "type": "field",

                       "value": "customer_id",

                       "label": "Customer",

                       "width": "25%"

                     },

                     {

                       "type": "field",

                       "value": "product_id",

                       "label": "Product (Catalog)",

                       "width": "25%"

                     }

                   ]

                 }]

             }]

         }]

     }]

 }

}

The chart view is used to display a chart.


It has the following structure:

```json

{

 "name": "Total turnover of bookings",

 "description": "This view displays the total turnover of the bookings.",

 "access": { "groups": ["booking.default.user"] },

 "controller": "core_model_chart",

 "layout": {

   "entity": "lodging\\sale\\booking\\Booking",

   "group_by": "range",

   "field": "date_from",

   "range_interval": "month",

   "range_from": "date.this.year.first",

   "range_to": "date.this.year.last",

   "datasets": [{

       "label": "Réservations CA HTVA",

       "operation": ["SUM", "object.total"],

       "domain": ["status", "<>", "quote"]

     },{

       "label": "Réservations CA TVAC",

       "operation": ["SUM", "object.price"],

       "domain": ["status", "<>", "quote"]

     }]

 }

}

• access: The access property allows defining which can have access to the view. In this case, the view is accessible only for those users that are in the booking user group.


  • controller: The controller property is used for defining the controller that is used for retrieve the data from.


  • layout.group_by: The group_by property is used for grouping the data by a range or a field. You need to define the field too for both.


  • layout.range_interval: The range_interval property is used for defining the interval of the range. You can use day, week, month, semester, year.


  • layout.range_from and range_to: The range_from and range_to properties are used for defining the range of the data. You can use date.this or date.prev which is the previous date.


  • datasets: The datasets property is used for defining the datasets of the chart. You can define multiple datasets.

A dataset is a set of data that is used to create the chart.


The dataset has the following properties:


  • label: The label of the dataset.
  • operation: The operation to use for the dataset. They are multiple type of operation:

   - ABS: absolute

   - AVG: average

   - COUNT: count

   - DIFF: difference

   - MAX: maximum

   - MIN: minimum

   - SUM: sum for get the total


  • domain: The domain of the dataset.

The i18n is used to translate the application in multiple languages.


There are two types of translations:


  • Model translations : Responsible for translating the model fields.


  • View translations: Responsible for translating the views.


  • View translations: The translation file is called: {ISO639-1 lang}[-{ISO-3166-1 country}].json


It is stored in the packages/{package_name}/i18n/{lang}/{class_name}.json directory of the package.

For authorizing a user to perfom an action or not, eQual uses the AccessController.


The AccessController uses several mechanisms to manage the access of the users:


  • ACL: Access Control List
  • ABAC: Attribute-Based Access Control
  • RBAC: Role-Based Access Control
  • PBAC: Policy-Based Access Control

You can access the values of an array using the index:

element in the array is at index 0, the second element is at index 1, and so on.

This basic guide doesn't go into further details about classes and objects but we can explain a little.


A class is a blueprint for creating objects. And an object is an instance of a class.


They can contain properties and methods.


A property is a variable hold inside the scope of the object or class that holds data, and a method is a function that performs an action and it's registered inside of the class.

```php

// Class definition

class Person {

 public $name = "John";

 public $age = 30;


 public function name() {

  return $this->name;

 }

}


// Object creation

$person = new Person();


echo $person->name; // Output: John

echo $person->name(); // Output: John
And its structure is like an array:
In the next, we'll see how to use PHP functions.
A function is a block of code that performs a specific task, they're used to avoid repeating the same code multiple times.
You can define a function using the following syntax:

```php

// We define the function

function say_hello() {

  echo "Hello, World!";

}


// We call the function

say_hello(); // Output: Hello, World!

You can also pass arguments to a function.


An argument is a value that you pass to a function when you call it.


We define the function sum with two arguments $a and $b both are integers.

I have added the type of the arguments and the return type of the function.


The type of the arguments:


(int $a, int $b) are both integers

the return type ...): int is also integer
And we can call the function with the two arguments:

PHP has a lot of native functions that you can use to perform common tasks.


For example, you can use the strlen() function to get the number of character that contains a string:

They're a lot of functions that you can use in PHP, you can find the list of the functions in the PHP documentation if you want.


The PHP documentation is available at PHP: PHP Manual - Manual and is translated in many languages.

Arithmetic operators are used to perform arithmetic operations on variables and values.


  • Addition (+): Performs addition.
  • Subtraction (-): Performs subtraction.
  • Multiplication (*): Performs multiplication.
  • Division (/): Performs division.
  • Modulus (%): Returns the remainder of a division.
  • Exponentiation (**): Performs exponentiation.


They're other arithmetic operators, but these are the most used.


For example, if you want to add the two variables $a and $b, you can use the addition operator:

Assignment operators are used to assign values to variables.


  • Equal (=): Assigns the value of the right operand to the left operand.
  • Addition assignment (+=): Adds the right operand to the left operand and assigns the result to the left operand.
  • Subtraction assignment (-=): Subtracts the right operand from the left operand and assigns the result to the left operand.
  • Concatenation assignment (.=): Appends the right operand to the left operand.


They're other assignment operators, but these are the most used.
For example, if you want to add the value of the variable $b to the variable $a, you can use the addition assignment

Comparison operators are used to compare two values.


  • Equal (==): Returns true if the values are equal.
  • Identical (===): Returns true if the values are equal and of the same type.
  • Not equal (!=): Returns true if the values are not equal.
  • Not identical (!==): Returns true if the values are not equal or not of the same type.
  • Greater than (>): Returns true if the left operand is greater than the right operand.
  • Less than (<): Returns true if the left operand is less than the right operand.
  • Greater than or equal to (>=): Returns true if the left operand is greater than or equal to the right operand.
  • Less than or equal to (<=): Returns true if the left operand is less than or equal to the right operand.


They're other comparison operators, but these are the most used.


For example, if you want to compare the value of the variable $a with the value of the variable $b, you can use the greater or equal than operator:

Logical operators are used to combine conditional statements.


  • And (&&): Returns true if both operands are true.
  • Or (||): Returns true if either operand is true.
  • Not (!): Returns true if the operand is false.


They're other logical operators, but these are the most used.


For example, if you want to check if the value of the $a and $b variables are correctly assigned, you can use the && operator:

```php

echo $a && $b; // Output: true


$a = null; // Assign null to the variable $a


echo $a && $b; // Output: false

In this chapter, you've learned the basics of PHP operators.


If you want to learn more about PHP operators, you can find the list of the operators in the PHP documentation at PHP: Operators - Manual.

The id method is used to get a collection of objects with the specified id.


For example, if you want to get the object with the id 1, you can use the id method:

Mostly, the Collection methods return itself, so you can chain the methods like in the previous example.


Remember to adapt the data to the format that you want to use and to get the data.

The search method is used to get a collection of objects matching the domain criteria.


The domain criteria is a list of conditions that the object must meet to be in the collection, it'll be more explained in the next chapter.


For example, if you want to get the objects with the title Task 1 you can use the search method:

The create method is used to create a new object instance.


For example, if you want to create a new object with the title Task 3 and the content, you can use the create method:

The update method is used to set new values for one or more object instances.


For example, if you want to update the object with the id 1 with the title Task 1 updated and the content, you can use the update method:

The delete method is used to delete the objects from the database. eQual has a soft deleting option feature.


The soft deleting feature is a way for say that an information in the database was deleted without is totally deleted in the database. The information is defined as deleted but is still peristed for futur purpose like the number of task that has been deleted.


Let's go delete the Task with the id 1:

```php

use yourPackageName\Task;


$task = Task::id(1)

  ->delete(

// The default value is false, if you want to delete the object permanently, you can set the value to true.

    permanent: false

  )

  ->first(true);

I'll show you the structure of the translation file.


A translation file is like this:

```json

{

 "name": "The translated name field descriptor of the Model",

 "plural": "The translated plural field descriptor of the Model",

 "description": "The translated description field descriptor of the Model",

 // The model fields translation

 "model": ...,

 // The view fields translation

 "view": ...,

 "error": ...

}
Each property of the model can be translated like this title property.

```json

{

 "model": {

  "title": {

   "label": "The translated label of the title field",

   "description": "The translated description of the title field",

   // The help is used for the tooltip of the field

   "help": "The translated help of the title field"

  },

  ...

 }

}
The view translations are placed inside the view property of the i18n file.

```json

{

 "view": {

  "form.default": {

   "name": "The translated name of the form",

   "description": "The translated description of the form",

   "layout": {

    "section.your_section_name": {

     "label": "The translated label of the section"

    }

   }

  },

  ...

 }

}
To mark a field a translatable, you need to add a multilang property to the field inside the getColumns method of the model class.

For working with the translations, you need to use a third argument in your model handler methods.


Like this:

```php

$lang = 'fr';


// Read the object and ge it's french translation

MyClass::ids($id)

    ->update($fields, $lang)

    ->read(['field1', 'field2'], $lang)

    ->first();

     

// Update the object with the french translation

MyClass::ids($id)

    ->update($fields, $lang);

The AccessController has some methods for managing the access of the users:


  • canPerform: Check if the user can perform an action based on its associated policies.
  • isCompliant: Check if the user is compliant with the policy at the collection level.
  • hasRole: Used at the object level in policy handlers or ``can`` methods.
  • hasRight: Used at the collection level for the CRUD operations.

The Collection class has some methods for managing the access of the users:


can: Check if the user can perform an action.

complies: Check if the user is compliant with the policy.

has: Check if the user has a role or a right.

do: Attempts to perform a specific action to a series of objects.

The ACL is used to manage the access of the users to the resources.


The ACL is a list of permissions that are associated with the users. Each ressource has a list of permissions.


It's a good practice to create Roles and Permissions with init data, like this when the package is initialized the roles and rights too.


The permissions are:


  • read: The user can read the ressource.
  • create: The user can create the ressource.
  • update: The user can update the ressource.
  • delete: The user can delete the ressource.
  • manage: The user can manage the ressource.

There are two default roles:


users: The default role for the users.

admins: The default role for the administrators.


The roles are used to manage the access of the users to the resources.
The groups are used to manage the access of the users to the resources.

The permissions are used to manage the access of the users to the resources.


Here's an example of init data permission:

```json

[{

  "name": "core\\Permission",

  "lang": "en",

  "description": "Grant READ permission on common objects (`core` package).",

  "data": [{

    "class_name": "core\\*",

    "domain": "",

    "group_id": 2,

    "user_id": null,

    "rights": 2

  }]

}]
The $this keyword is used inside of a class for handling it's own properties and methods.
You can define classes and objects using the following syntax:

The eQual framework use a widely used pattern for executing it's application, The MVC pattern.


MVC means Model View Controller.


In this chapter we will look at the different functionalities in eQual that are linked to this MVC pattern.
